thread.title: Is Tony Abbott preparing to strike?
thread.title_full: Is Tony Abbott preparing to strike?

author: Latika Bourke
title: Is Tony Abbott preparing to strike?
text:
Print Is Tony Abbott preparing to strike? 
Every Monday to Friday I'll be delivering a personally-curated newsletter. Call it the double espresso of news â€“ the morning news kickstart for busy people who want to know what they need to know before they get going. 
Is Tony Abbott about to launch his own Ides of March strike? SHARE Former prime minister Tony Abbott says he would cut the Renewable Energy Target. Photo: Rick Rycroft 
How else to explain Wednesday's extraordinary interview with conservative commentator Andrew Bolt in which he unloaded on the government as "drifting to defeat" and set out a plan which he claims would correct the Coalition's poor standing in the polls, and haemorrhaging of votes to One Nation? [ Sky News ] 
He recorded the interview before delivering a blistering critique of the Turnbull government in a speech launching a collection of essays called Making Australia Right . [ Full speech ] [ James Massola/Fairfax ] 
"The gloves are off," observed Bolt. [ Herald Sun ] 
With Parliament due back next week this could boil over and that may be what Abbott intends. Ironically, it would come of the back of the best two weeks Turnbull has had in the job although as Michelle Grattan notes, the government's gains from Turnbull's bullish attack on Shorten have been so far minimal if at all. [ The Conversation ] Advertisement 
If Abbott believes he has the numbers in the partyroom, well over his unhelpful interventions, to make a comeback he possess a greater lack of self-awareness than we've previously appreciated. 
One Twitter follower whimsically observed that for someone who hates Kevin Rudd, Tony Abbott spends a lot of time copying him. Funny indeed but to me this looks more like the mimicry of another former Labor leader - Simon Crean, when he took it upon himself to challenge Julia Gillard for the leadership as a way of blowing open Kevin Rudd's destabilisation of Gillard. 
The move was disastrous for Crean. Rudd sat tight, Crean didn't have a hope and was sacked from Cabinet. His career never recovered and he resigned from parliament in 2013. 
Minister for Immigration and Border Protection Peter Dutton. Photo: Alex Ellinghausen 
Colleagues think its possible that Abbott is about to embark on a "suicide bomber" mission. The eventual successor, intended or otherwise, could be Peter Dutton, who as Immigration Minister gets a tough hearing in the media but has been quietly gaining support internally. This is largely because he was not part of the mission to install Turnbull but has proved himself a reliable Cabinet colleague of the PM, despite being the leading conservative in the lower house. 
The fraccas over whether or not the deal with the US to take our asylum seekers from Manus Island and Nauru is a people swap or not (it clearly is as Australia is accepting refugees from Costa Rica) is not the dunderhead mistake from Dutton (who said as much with Bolt this week) that some people are making it out to be. 
It was deliberate. He is signalling that he is a straight-talking conservative and that he understands voters are sick of political sophistry and pretence. Although he was the one who ended up backing down after being "corrected" by Julie Bishop, Dutton's willingness to speak plainly could see him awarded the eventual political victory because he gets marks internally and externally for saying what voters already know is true. 
Treasurer Scott Morrison. Photo: Andrew Meares 
What should also not be missed is that during Bolt and Abbott's love-in on Sky, the pair sledged Julie Bishop as disloyal in praising Dutton and notably did not mention Scott Morrison. He was once seen as an heir to the leadership but has floundered in the Treasury role. 
But there's no guarantee of what will happen if Abbott presses the thermo-nuclear button. Remember when Crean blew himself up it reinforced Gillard's position for a few more months longer. 
But change or no change, Julie Bishop will go down as the "forever undefeated" No 2. writes Graham Richardson. [ The Australian ] 2. Aust politics - the rest of 
Donald Trump reportedly accused Malcolm Turnbull of trying to send the US the "next Boston bomber." Photo: AP 
Attempts are being made for Turnbull to meet Trump in New York in May for what would be the two leaders' first meeting. [ Peter Hartcher/Fairfax ] 
Overnight Turnbull spoke with Prime Minister Theresa May about the Middle East and Brexit. Foreign Minister Julie Bishop was in London meeting Boris Johnson and the Minister for Brexit David Davis. [ My report/Fairfax ] 
Indonesian President Joko Widodo will propose joint patrols of the South China Sea during his visit to Australia this weekend. [ Amanda Hodge/The Australian ] 
Former Treasury Secretary Ken Henry on why we should outsource climate policy to the business sector because politics is broken is a fascinating read. [ Laura Tingle/Financial Review ] 
Henry's frustrations with the political tribalism are spot on, says David Crowe. [ The Australian ] 
Benjamin Netanyahu visiting Moriah College in Queens Park, Sydney. Photo: Renee Nowtarger 
Former Labor Leader Kim Beazley does not back recognising Palestine, putting him at odds with Kevin Rudd (no surprises there) but also Bob Hawke, Bob Carr and Gareth Evans. [ Paul Maley/The Australian ] 
A group of sitting Labor MPs, many long supporters of Palestine, are calling for recognition of Palestine, making Bill Shorten's meeting with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu today a little awkward. [ Fergus Hunter/Fairfax ] 
Opposition Leader Bill Shorten. Photo: Alex Ellinghausen Dennis Atkins believes the Fair Work Commission's independent ruling to cut some Sunday penalty rates may have handed Bill Shorten the next election. [ Courier Mail ] 
The FWC's ruling is backed by The Sydney Morning Herald , often accused of being left-wing by right-wing MPs. [ Editorial ] 
"Hallelujah!" cries the Financial Review . [ Editorial ] 
And Bill Shorten is the politician who made it happen, applauds The Australian . [ Editorial ] 3. Mosul Airport 
Smoke rises after an airstrike near Mosul earlier this week. Photo: The Canadian Press/ AP 
Iraqi forces took just hours to reclaim Mosul airport from Islamic State. [ Reuters ] 
And again I really can't recommend Quentin Sommerville's live-tweeting of the operation to take back Mosul enough.
